ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: We already gave our evaluation to the instructor in the end of the class.
Question 11: I give the course the overall 2 because the course should be a semester long class since it has a lot to cover and 6 weeks were not sufficient.

One of my best classes at F&ES. The mixed format also worked well, as I received more feedback from the instructors than I have in almost any other course. Very fast and packed course - lots of important literature covered and I learned a lot from my independent project paper.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The selection of readings were excellent.
We already gave our evaluation to the instructor in the end of the class.
I liked the online component.

It was great to preview materials including pre-recorded lectures and then to have in class discussion session. Although sometimes the discussion was challenging since there were so many materials had to be covered in ahead of the class, it was helpful to get a sense of concepts that we learned.
The Discussion group was incredible.

A new way of teaching where students have to read the materials first and come well prepared in class to discuss with the instructor. Beside from that, the content itself was very compelling since reforestation is very important in this world where climate change is a big issue, mostly driven by human activities, causing forest and species loss. Understanding the technics and social values for successful reforestation is very important.
The use of actual case studies
The level of feedback, the online format, the instructor's knowledge of the subject

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: The course is too short to cover the material properly, and the discussion sections are too short to properly discuss all the material.

Discussion seemed overwhelmed by trying to summarize the readings and thoughts/questions. It may have been valuable to break discussion into smaller groups or with fewer readings to get beyond thinking about "readings" and thinking more about on-the-ground implications of the course material.
We already gave our evaluation to the instructor in the end of the class.
The way that the reading materials are used in class. Too many readings and no time to reflect on them.

I felt the in class discussion couldn't fully cover all the materials that we previewed before the class since there were multiple materials. I wonder if it would be better to have less materials and have more focused discussion or have more class time to cover everything deeply.
The online material should be made available to the students beyond the length of the class for reference.
Time and workload.
Case studies should be more widely focused and not just specific continents
The class workload is very condensed over 6 weeks and would do better if it is spread out over a the entire term. Field trips would also be something interesting to add to the course.

The quizzes felt a little random and nitpicky to me. It seems like they are perhaps worth a little too many points for being such as small part of the overall scope of the course. I spent about 100 times more time working on my final paper and on the weekly questions.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: The discussion sections should either be smaller in size or longer to be able to discuss both the readings and the online lectures.

Course lectures were in the form of videos which made for a more rewarding class time centered around discussion. Some of the videos were of better quality and more cohesive than others, which could be worked on to make the course better
Longer discussion hours.
Very effective.
The discussion could be better facilitated by providing key questions for discussion prior to the meetings.
Integrally connected. The facilitation of the discussions was great. In particular, I liked Eva's powerpoint summary of the readings.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: Fit very well because I am keen on learning tropical forest management
Yes it fitted well with my overall program in terms of covering every aspect of restoration in the tropics, from policies to biophysical contents.
It really fits to my background as forest ecologist interested in payement for ecosystem services and improved sustainable forest management
I wanted a dose of forestry that wasn't too heavy but one that covered the basics. This course fulfilled that
I'm interested in tropical and temperate forest management. This course provides a useful way to think about restoration.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I am very interested in this topic in my future career.
Because of the content of the class and the amazing instructor!

I intended to take this class to learn more practical knowledge on how communities could manage tropical forests and resources effectively. Also how it could be managed in relation to other stakeholders.
I identify myself as tropical ecologist and this was important to me.
I wanted to learn more about forest system restoration methods
I like Dr. Ashton's teaching style and this course looked very interesting.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes, there was a lot of exposure to the necessary concepts. I don't think more could be gleaned without on-the-ground or specific planning experience. (I don't know if there's any way to design exercises that would offer this kind of opportunity)
Beyond my expectation.
Partially. A field component would significantly improve the course.
Yes it was useful; yet a lot of knowledge was totally new areas that I had to spend more time that I expected to catch up the pace of class.
Yes.
I think so.
Very much
Far exceeded them.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: I would say that they should consider how well the learn from video lectures compared to in person lectures, since they are very different.
The workload is heavier, but the class only runs for 6 weeks. If you are interested in learning forest restoration from all aspects (ecology, social, economy), then this is the right class for you.
Use your time wisely. The course is intense for a short period of time. Yet it yields great rewards, if knowledge is what you seek.
If they have the same interest as me or if they professional lives will take them to run projects with local communities--they should indeed take this class
Do it! This is one of the best courses I took at F&ES. Very well considered and executed.
